description: From Middle English berye, from Old English berġe, from Proto-West Germanic *baʀi, from Proto-Germanic *bazją.
Cognate with Saterland Frisian Bäie, West Flemish beier, German Beere, Icelandic ber, Danish bær.
The slang sense "police car" may come from the lights on the vehicles' roofs.

entries.meaning: A small succulent fruit, of any one of many varieties.
(botany) A soft fruit which develops from a single ovary and contains seeds not encased in pits.
One of the ova or eggs of a fish.
(slang, US, African-American English) A police car.

examples: Four rounds and Enright still on his feet and a hundred and fifty thousand berries gone if he stays two more!

verbs.description: berry (third-person singular simple present berries, present participle berrying, simple past and past participle berried)

examples: On summer days Grandma used to take us berrying, whether we wanted to go or not.

description: From Middle English berȝe, berghe, from Old English beorġe, dative form of beorg (“mountain, hill, mound, barrow”), from Proto-West Germanic *berg, from Proto-Germanic *bergaz (“mountain, hill”). More at barrow.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly dialectal) A mound; a barrow.

description: From Middle English bery (“a burrow”). More at burrow.

entries.meaning: (dialectal) A burrow, especially a rabbit's burrow.

description: From Middle English beryen, berien, from Old English *berian (found only in past participle ġebered (“crushed, kneaded, harassed, oppressed, vexed”)), from Proto-West Germanic *barjan, from Proto-Germanic *barjaną (“to beat, hit”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰerH- (“to rip, cut, split, grate”).
Cognate with Scots berry, barry (“to thresh, thrash”), German beren (“to beat, knead”), Icelandic berja (“to beat”), Latin feriō (“strike, hit”, verb).

verbs.description: berry (third-person singular simple present berries, present participle berrying, simple past and past participle berried)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To beat; give a beating to; thrash.
